doom.driver: Iran and the U.S. lean into gunboat diplomacy as nuclear talks hang in balance.
doom.blurb: TWO CARRIERS, ZERO DEALS, ONE DRILL WITH RUSSIA
doom.summary: The Iran situation is doing that thing where it refuses to resolve itself — Tehran is now running naval drills with Russia while the US parks a second carrier nearby and Trump reportedly discusses strike options for as early as Saturday. Meanwhile the Ukraine peace talks lasted a brisk two hours before collapsing, and Sudan has officially earned the word 'genocide' from a UN fact-finding mission. It's not a single catastrophe — it's a stress test of every guardrail simultaneously.

factors.name: Geopolitics
factors.detail: Iran-US standoff escalates with Russia-Iran naval drills, second US carrier deployed, and reported strike timeline of days — a meaningful escalation from prior posturing.

factors.name: Governance
factors.detail: ICC judges describe life under Trump sanctions, South Korea's Yoon gets life for martial law, and Peru burns through its eighth president in a decade — democratic institutions globally under stress.

factors.name: AI Capability
factors.detail: Osborne warns nations without AI will be 'weaker and poorer,' Meta locks in millions of Nvidia chips, and AI spending hits $2.5 trillion — the acceleration narrative is loud but not yet alarming.

factors.name: Alignment
factors.detail: Google DeepMind calls for scrutiny of LLM moral behavior, and a defense company demos AI agents that 'blow things up' — concerning but contained to research and demonstration stages.

factors.name: Wild Card
factors.detail: Former Prince Andrew arrested, Sudan genocide confirmed, and 1,000+ Kenyans allegedly trafficked to fight in Ukraine — the ambient chaos index is running hot.

dawn.driver: Viagra and shingles vaccine show surprising promise against Alzheimer's. A major new study has spotlighted three familiar medicines that could take on an unexpected new role in the fight against Alzheimer's disease — with a shingles vaccine emerging as the front-runner.
dawn.blurb: FAMILIAR MEDICINES MAY CRACK ALZHEIMER'S CODE
dawn.summary: On a day heavy with geopolitical turbulence and humanitarian crisis, science quietly delivered what may be one of the most significant medical signals in years: medicines already trusted by millions could help defeat Alzheimer's disease, the condition that robs people of themselves. The shingles vaccine — already widely available and proven safe — emerging as a front-runner is extraordinary, because it means protection could scale globally without waiting for novel drug pipelines. Alongside DMT showing genuine antidepressant results in clinical trials and a sodium-ion battery that simultaneously stores energy and desalinates seawater, today's science headlines remind us that human ingenuity keeps compounding even when the news cycle doesn't.

factors.name: Science
factors.detail: Existing, accessible medicines showing promise against Alzheimer's represents a potential step-change in how quickly treatment could reach the hundreds of millions affected worldwide.

factors.name: Human Spirit
factors.detail: South Korea's courts sentenced a former president to life for insurrection — democratic institutions holding the line under pressure, exactly as designed.

factors.name: Environment
factors.detail: A new sodium-ion battery that stores twice the energy and desalinates seawater simultaneously points toward solving two existential resource challenges with one elegant technology.

factors.name: Cooperation
factors.detail: Vietnam Airlines and carriers signed deals for nearly 100 Boeing jets during diplomatic visits, showing trade and relationship-building continuing through geopolitical headwinds.

factors.name: Wild Card
factors.detail: AI is accelerating the hunt for next-generation magnetic materials that could eliminate rare earth magnets in electric vehicles — a quiet revolution in clean transport supply chains.
